[](/wiki/File:Location_Southern_Ocean.svg "Enlarge")

The Southern Ocean, as delineated by the draft 4th edition of the
[International Hydrographic
Organization](/wiki/International_Hydrographic_Organization "International
Hydrographic Organization")'s _Limits of Oceans and Seas_ (2002).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Antarctica-
Region.png/300px-Antarctica-Region.png)](/wiki/File:Antarctica-Region.png)

[](/wiki/File:Antarctica-Region.png "Enlarge")

A general delineation of the [Antarctic
Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic Convergence"), sometimes
used by scientists as the demarcation of the Southern Ocean.

The **Southern Ocean** , also known as the **Antarctic Ocean**[1] or the
**Austral Ocean** ,[2][note 4] comprises the southernmost waters of the [World
Ocean](/wiki/World_Ocean "World Ocean"), generally taken to be south of [60° S
latitude](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south") and encircling
[Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica").[6] As such, it is regarded as the
fourth-largest of the five principal [oceanic](/wiki/Ocean "Ocean") divisions:
smaller than the [Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean"),
[Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"), and [Indian
Oceans](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") but larger than the [Arctic
Ocean](/wiki/Arctic_Ocean "Arctic Ocean").[7] This [ocean
zone](/wiki/Oceanic_zone "Oceanic zone") is where cold, northward flowing
waters from the [Antarctic](/wiki/Antarctic "Antarctic") mix with warmer
[subantarctic](/wiki/Subantarctic "Subantarctic") waters.

By way of his voyages in the 1770s, [Captain James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook
"James Cook") proved that waters encompassed the southern latitudes of the
globe. Since then, geographers have disagreed on the Southern Ocean's northern
boundary or even existence, considering the waters as various parts of the
Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans, instead. However, according to Commodore
John Leech of the [International Hydrographic
Organization](/wiki/International_Hydrographic_Organization "International
Hydrographic Organization") (IHO), this situation has no scientific sense
since it has different ecosystem and life from the three oceans mentioned
before and is located on a southern portion of Earth, hence the name of an
ocean.[8] This remains the current official policy of the IHO, since a 2000
revision of its definitions including the Southern Ocean as the waters south
of the 60th parallel has not yet been adopted. Others regard the seasonally-
fluctuating [Antarctic Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic
Convergence") as the natural boundary.[9]

## Definitions and
use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Definitions and use")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/Iceedgekils.gif)](/wiki/File:Iceedgekils.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Iceedgekils.gif "Enlarge")

Pulsating pack-ice around Antarctica reflects the various definitions of the
Southern Ocean

Borders and names for oceans and seas were internationally agreed when the
[International Hydrographic Bureau](/wiki/International_Hydrographic_Bureau
"International Hydrographic Bureau") (IHB), the precusor to the IHO, convened
the First International Conference on 24 July 1919. The IHO then published
these in its _Limits of Oceans and Seas_ , the first edition being 1928. Since
the first edition, the limits of the Southern Ocean have moved progressively
southwards; since 1953, it has been omitted from the official publication and
left to local hydrographic offices to determine their own limits. The IHO
included the ocean and its definition as the waters south of 60°S in its year
2000 revisions, but this has not been formally adopted, due to continuing
impasses over other areas of the text, such as the [naming
dispute](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan_naming_dispute "Sea of Japan naming dispute") over
the [Sea of Japan](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan "Sea of Japan"). The 2000 IHO
definition, however, was circulated in a draft edition in 2002 and is used by
some within the IHO and by some other organizations such as the US [Central
Intelligence Agency](/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency "Central Intelligence
Agency")[7] and [Merriam-Webster](/wiki/Merriam-Webster_Dictionary "Merriam-
Webster Dictionary").[note 5][10] [Australian](/wiki/Australia "Australia")
authorities regard the Southern Ocean as lying immediately south of
Australia.[11][12] The [National Geographic
Society](/wiki/National_Geographic_Society "National Geographic Society") does
not recognize the ocean,[2] depicting it (if at all) in a typeface different
from the other world oceans; instead, it shows the Pacific, Atlantic, and
Indian Oceans extending to Antarctica on both its print and on line
maps.[13][note 6] Map publishers using the term Southern Ocean on their maps
include Hema Maps[15] and GeoNova.[16]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/The_shrinking_Southern_Ocean.png/800px-The_shrinking_Southern_Ocean.png)](/wiki/File:The_shrinking_Southern_Ocean.png) [](/wiki/File:The_shrinking_Southern_Ocean.png "Enlarge") The [International Hydrographic Organization](/wiki/International_Hydrographic_Organization "International Hydrographic Organization")'s delineation of the "Southern Ocean" has moved steadily southwards since the original 1928 edition of its _Limits of Oceans and Seas_. [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") continues to view the ocean as beginning at its southern coast. The 1953 limits shown are those of [Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), as identified in third edition. Others continue to view the [Antarctic Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic Convergence") as the natural boundary of the Southern Ocean, regardless of political agreements.[6] |  [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Antarctica_Map.png/360px-Antarctica_Map.png)](/wiki/File:Antarctica_Map.png) [](/wiki/File:Antarctica_Map.png "Enlarge") Southern [Ocean](/wiki/Ocean "Ocean") Antarctica Map.  
---|---  
  
### Pre-20th-century
definitions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Pre-20th-century definitions")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/A_new_map_of_Africk%2C_shewing_its_present_general_divisions_cheif_cities_or_towns%2C_rivers%2C_mountain_%26c._%288250932292%29.jpg/220px-
A_new_map_of_Africk%2C_shewing_its_present_general_divisions_cheif_cities_or_towns%2C_rivers%2C_mountain_%26c._%288250932292%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_new_map_of_Africk,_shewing_its_present_general_divisions_cheif_cities_or_towns,_rivers,_mountain_%26c._\(8250932292\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_new_map_of_Africk,_shewing_its_present_general_divisions_cheif_cities_or_towns,_rivers,_mountain_%26c._\(8250932292\).jpg
"Enlarge")

"Southern Ocean" as an alternative name for the [Aethiopian
Ocean](/wiki/Aethiopian_Ocean "Aethiopian Ocean") in a 1700 map of Africa

"Southern Ocean" is an obsolete name for the Pacific Ocean or South Pacific,
coined by [Vasco Núñez de Balboa](/wiki/Vasco_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez_de_Balboa "Vasco
Núñez de Balboa"), the first European to discover it, who approached it from
the north.[17] The "South Seas" is a less archaic synonym. A 1745 British [Act
of Parliament](/wiki/Act_of_Parliament "Act of Parliament") established a
prize for discovering a [Northwest Passage](/wiki/Northwest_Passage "Northwest
Passage") to "the Western and Southern Ocean of _America_ ".[18]

Authors using "Southern Ocean" to name the waters encircling the unknown
southern polar regions used varying limits. [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook
"James Cook")'s account of [his second
voyage](/wiki/Second_voyage_of_James_Cook "Second voyage of James Cook")
implies [New Caledonia](/wiki/New_Caledonia "New Caledonia") borders it.[19]
Peacock's 1795 _Geographical Dictionary_ said it lay "to the southward of
America and Africa";[20] John Payne in 1796 used 40 degrees as the northern
limit;[21] the 1827 _Edinburgh Gazetteer_ used 50 degrees.[22] The _Family
Magazine_ in 1835 divided the "Great Southern Ocean" into the "Southern Ocean"
and the "Antarctick [_sic_] Ocean" along the Antarctic Circle, with the
northern limit of the Southern Ocean being lines joining Cape Horn, the Cape
of Good Hope, Van Diemen's Land and the south of New Zealand.[23]

The United Kingdom's [South Australia Act 1834](/wiki/South_Australia_Act_1834
"South Australia Act 1834") described the waters forming the southern limit of
the new colony of [South Australia](/wiki/South_Australia "South Australia")
as "the Southern Ocean". The [Colony of Victoria](/wiki/Colony_of_Victoria
"Colony of Victoria")'s Legislative Council Act of 1881 delimited part of the
division of [Bairnsdale](/wiki/Bairnsdale "Bairnsdale") as "along the [New
South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South Wales") boundary to the Southern
ocean".[24]

### 1928
delineation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1928 delineation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_1st_Edition_-_1928.jpg/220px-
Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_1st_Edition_-_1928.jpg)](/wiki/File:Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_1st_Edition_-_1928.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_1st_Edition_-_1928.jpg "Enlarge")

**1928 First Edition** of _Limits of Oceans and Seas_ with original IHO
delineation of Southern Ocean abutting land-masses.[25]

In the 1928 first edition of _Limits of Oceans and Seas_ , the Southern Ocean
was delineated by land-based limits: Antarctica to the south, and South
America, Africa, Australia, and [Broughton Island, New
Zealand](/wiki/Broughton_Island,_New_Zealand "Broughton Island, New Zealand")
to the north.

The detailed land-limits used were from [Cape Horn](/wiki/Cape_Horn "Cape
Horn") in South America eastwards to [Cape Agulhas](/wiki/Cape_Agulhas "Cape
Agulhas") in Africa, then further eastwards to the southern coast of mainland
Australia to [Cape Leeuwin](/wiki/Cape_Leeuwin "Cape Leeuwin"), [Western
Australia](/wiki/Western_Australia "Western Australia"). From Cape Leeuwin,
the limit then followed eastwards along the coast of mainland Australia to
[Cape Otway](/wiki/Cape_Otway "Cape Otway"),
[Victoria](/wiki/Victoria_\(Australia\) "Victoria \(Australia\)"), then
southwards across [Bass Strait](/wiki/Bass_Strait "Bass Strait") to [Cape
Wickham](/wiki/Cape_Wickham "Cape Wickham"), [King
Island](/wiki/King_Island_\(Tasmania\) "King Island \(Tasmania\)"), along the
west coast of King Island, then the remainder of the way south across Bass
Strait to [Cape Grim](/wiki/Cape_Grim "Cape Grim"), [Tasmania](/wiki/Tasmania
"Tasmania"). The limit then followed the west coast of Tasmania southwards to
the [South East Cape](/wiki/South_East_Cape "South East Cape") and then went
eastwards to Broughton Island, New Zealand, before returning to Cape Horn.[25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_2nd_Edition_-_1st_July_1937.jpg/220px-
Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_2nd_Edition_-_1st_July_1937.jpg)](/wiki/File:Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_2nd_Edition_-_1st_July_1937.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Limit_of_Oceans_and_Seas_-_2nd_Edition_-_1st_July_1937.jpg
"Enlarge")

**1937 Second Edition** of _Limits of Oceans and Seas_ showing IHO's pre-1953
delineation of Southern Ocean moved southwards.[26]

### 1937
delineation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1937 delineation")]

The northern limits of the Southern Ocean were moved southwards in the IHO's
1937 second edition of the _Limits of Oceans and Seas_. From this edition,
much of the ocean's northern limit ceased to abut land masses.

In the second edition, the Southern Ocean then extended from Antarctica
northwards to latitude 40°S between [Cape Agulhas](/wiki/Cape_Agulhas "Cape
Agulhas") in Africa (long. 20°E) and [Cape Leeuwin](/wiki/Cape_Leeuwin "Cape
Leeuwin") in Western Australia (long. 115°E), and extended to latitude 55°S
between [Auckland Island](/wiki/Auckland_Island "Auckland Island") of New
Zealand (165 or 166°E east) and [Cape Horn](/wiki/Cape_Horn "Cape Horn") in
South America (67°W).[26]

As is discussed in more detail below (see section on '2002 delineation'),
prior to the 2002 (draft) edition the limits of oceans explicitly excluded the
seas lying within each of them. The [Great Australian
Bight](/wiki/Great_Australian_Bight "Great Australian Bight") was unnamed in
the 1928 edition, and delineated as shown in the figure above in the 1937
edition. It therefore encompassed former Southern Ocean waters (as designated
in 1928) but was technically not inside any of the three adjacent oceans by
1937. In the 2002 draft edition, the IHO have designated 'seas' as being
subdivisions within 'oceans', so the Bight would have still been within the
Southern Ocean in 1937 if the 2002 convention were in place then. To perform
direct comparisons of current and former limits of oceans (for example to
compare surface areas) it is necessary to consider, or at least be aware of,
how the 2002 change in IHO terminology for 'seas' can affect the comparison.

### 1953
delineation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 1953 delineation")]

The Southern Ocean did not appear in the 1953 third edition and a note in the
publication read:

> The Antarctic or Southern Ocean has been omitted from this publication as
> the majority of opinions received since the issue of the 2nd Edition in 1937
> are to the effect that there exists no real justification for applying the
> term Ocean to this body of water, the northern limits of which are difficult
> to lay down owing to their seasonal change. The limits of the Atlantic,
> Pacific and Indian Oceans have therefore been extended South to the
> Antarctic Continent.
>
> Hydrographic Offices who issue separate publications dealing with this area
> are therefore left to decide their own northern limits (Great Britain uses
> Latitude of 55 South.)

Instead, in the IHO 1953 publication, the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans
were extended southward, the Indian and Pacific Oceans (which had not
previously touched pre 1953, as per the first and second editions) now abutted
at the meridian of [South East Cape](/wiki/South_East_Cape "South East Cape"),
and the southern limits of the [Great Australian
Bight](/wiki/Great_Australian_Bight "Great Australian Bight") and the [Tasman
Sea](/wiki/Tasman_Sea "Tasman Sea") were moved northwards.[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Pacific_Ocean_-
_en_IHO.png/250px-Pacific_Ocean_-_en_IHO.png)](/wiki/File:Pacific_Ocean_-
_en_IHO.png)

[](/wiki/File:Pacific_Ocean_-_en_IHO.png "Enlarge")

The **Pacific Ocean** as example of terminology concerning seas: the area
inside the black line includes the seas included in the Pacific Ocean prior to
2002 and the darker blue areas are its informal current borders, following the
recreation of the Southern Ocean and the reinclusion of marginal seas.[28]

### 2002 (draft)
delineation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 2002 \(draft\) delineation")]

The IHO readdressed the question of the Southern Ocean in a survey in 2000. Of
its 68 member nations, 28 responded, and all responding members except
[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina "Argentina") agreed to redefine the ocean,
reflecting the importance placed by oceanographers on ocean currents. The
proposal for the name _Southern Ocean_ won 18 votes, beating the alternative
_Antarctic Ocean_. Half of the votes supported a definition of the ocean's
northern limit at [60°S](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south")
(with no land interruptions at this latitude), with the other 14 votes cast
for other definitions, mostly [50°S](/wiki/50th_parallel_south "50th parallel
south"), but a few for as far north as [35°S](/wiki/35th_parallel_south "35th
parallel south").

A draft fourth edition of _Limits of Oceans and Seas_ was circulated to IHO
member states in August 2002 (sometimes referred to as the "2000 edition" as
it summarized the progress to 2000).[29] It has yet to be published due to
'areas of concern' by several countries relating to various naming issues
around the world – primarily the [Sea of Japan naming
dispute](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan_naming_dispute "Sea of Japan naming dispute") –
and there have been various changes, 60 seas were given new names, and even
the name of the publication was changed.[30] A reservation had also been
lodged by Australia regarding the Southern Ocean limits.[31] Effectively, the
3rd edition (which did not delineate the Southern Ocean leaving delineation to
local hydrographic offices) has yet to be superseded.

Despite this, the 4th edition definition has partial _de facto_ usage by many
nations, scientists and organisations such as the U.S. (the [Central
Intelligence Agency](/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency "Central Intelligence
Agency") [World Factbook](/wiki/World_Factbook "World Factbook") uses
"Southern Ocean" but none of the other new sea names within the "Southern
Ocean" such as "[Cosmonauts Sea](/wiki/Cosmonauts_Sea "Cosmonauts Sea")") and
[Merriam-Webster](/wiki/Merriam-Webster_Dictionary "Merriam-Webster
Dictionary"),[7][10][14] scientists and nations – and even by some within the
IHO.[32] Some nations' hydrographic offices have defined their own boundaries;
the United Kingdom used the [55°S parallel](/wiki/55th_parallel_south "55th
parallel south") for example.[27] Other organisations favour more northerly
limits for the Southern Ocean. For example, the _[Encyclopædia
Britannica](/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica,_Inc. "Encyclopædia Britannica,
Inc.")_ describes the Southern Ocean as extending as far north as South
America, and confers great significance on the [Antarctic
Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic Convergence"), yet its
description of the Indian Ocean contradicts this, describing the Indian Ocean
as extending south to Antarctica.[12][33]

Other sources, such as the [National Geographic
Society](/wiki/National_Geographic_Society "National Geographic Society"),
show the [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"),
[Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") and [Indian](/wiki/Indian_Ocean
"Indian Ocean") Oceans as extending to Antarctica on its maps, although
articles on the National Geographic web site have begun to reference the
Southern Ocean.[14]

In [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"),
[cartographical](/wiki/Cartography "Cartography") authorities define the
Southern Ocean as including the entire body of water between Antarctica and
the south coasts of Australia and [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New
Zealand"), and up to 60°s elsewhere.[34] Coastal maps of
[Tasmania](/wiki/Tasmania "Tasmania") and [South
Australia](/wiki/South_Australia "South Australia") label the sea areas as
_Southern Ocean_ ,[35] while [Cape Leeuwin](/wiki/Cape_Leeuwin "Cape Leeuwin")
in [Western Australia](/wiki/Western_Australia "Western Australia") is
described as the point where the Indian and Southern Oceans meet.[36]

A radical shift from past IHO practices (1928–1953) was also seen in the 2002
draft edition when the IHO delineated 'seas' as being subdivisions that lay
within the boundaries of 'oceans'. While the IHO are often considered the
authority for such conventions, the shift brought them into line with the
practices of other publications (e.g. the CIA _World Fact Book_) which already
adopted the principle that seas are contained within oceans. This difference
in practice is markedly seen for the **Pacific Ocean** in the adjacent figure.
Thus, for example, previously the [Tasman Sea](/wiki/Tasman_Sea "Tasman Sea")
between Australia and New Zealand was not regarded by the IHO as being part of
the Pacific, but as of the 2002 draft edition it is.

The new delineation of seas being subdivisions of oceans has avoided the need
to interrupt the northern boundary of the Southern Ocean where intersected by
[Drake Passage](/wiki/Drake_Passage "Drake Passage") which includes all of the
waters from South America to the Antarctic coast, nor interrupt it for the
[Scotia Sea](/wiki/Scotia_Sea "Scotia Sea"), which also extends below the 60th
parallel south. The new delineation of seas has also meant that the long-time
named seas around Antarctica, excluded from the 1953 edition (the 1953 map did
not even extend that far south), are 'automatically' part of the Southern
Ocean.

## History of
exploration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: History of exploration")]

Main article: [History of Antarctica](/wiki/History_of_Antarctica "History of
Antarctica")

### The unknown southern
land[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: The unknown southern land")]

See also: [Terra Australis](/wiki/Terra_Australis "Terra Australis")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/OrteliusWorldMap1570.jpg/220px-
OrteliusWorldMap1570.jpg)](/wiki/File:OrteliusWorldMap1570.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:OrteliusWorldMap1570.jpg "Enlarge")

1564 _Typus Orbis Terrarum_ , a map by [Abraham
Ortelius](/wiki/Abraham_Ortelius "Abraham Ortelius") showed the imagined link
between the proposed continent of Antarctica and [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America").

Exploration of the Southern Ocean was inspired by a belief in the existence of
a _Terra Australis_ —a vast continent in the far south of the globe to
"balance" the northern lands of [Eurasia](/wiki/Eurasia "Eurasia") and [North
Africa](/wiki/North_Africa "North Africa")—which had existed since the times
of [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy"). The doubling of the [Cape of Good
Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape of Good Hope") in 1487 by [Bartolomeu
Dias](/wiki/Bartolomeu_Dias "Bartolomeu Dias") first brought explorers within
touch of the Antarctic cold, and proved that there was an ocean separating
[Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa") from any Antarctic land that might exist.
[Ferdinand Magellan](/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan "Ferdinand Magellan"), who
passed through the [Strait of Magellan](/wiki/Strait_of_Magellan "Strait of
Magellan") in 1520, assumed that the islands of [Tierra del
Fuego](/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego "Tierra del Fuego") to the south were an
extension of this unknown southern land. In 1564, [Abraham
Ortelius](/wiki/Abraham_Ortelius "Abraham Ortelius") published his first map,
_Typus Orbis Terrarum_ , an eight-leaved wall map of the world, on which he
identified the _[Regio Patalis](/wiki/Regio_Patalis "Regio Patalis")_ with
_[Locach](/wiki/Locach "Locach")_ as a northward extension of the _[Terra
Australis](/wiki/Terra_Australis "Terra Australis")_ , reaching as far as [New
Guinea](/wiki/New_Guinea "New Guinea").[37][38]

European geographers continued to connect the coast of Tierra del Fuego with
the coast of New Guinea on their globes, and allowing their imaginations to
run riot in the vast unknown spaces of the south Atlantic, south
[Indian](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") and [Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean
"Pacific Ocean") oceans they sketched the outlines of the _Terra Australis
Incognita_ ("Unknown Southern Land"), a vast continent stretching in parts
into the tropics. The search for this great south land was a leading motive of
explorers in the 16th and the early part of the 17th centuries.

The [Spaniard](/wiki/Spanish_people "Spanish people") [Gabriel de
Castilla](/wiki/Gabriel_de_Castilla "Gabriel de Castilla"), who claimed having
sighted "snow-covered mountains" beyond the [64° S](/wiki/64th_parallel_south
"64th parallel south") in 1603, is recognized as the first explorer that
discovered the continent of Antarctica, although he was ignored in his time.

In 1606, [Pedro Fernández de Quirós](/wiki/Pedro_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Quir%C3%B3s
"Pedro Fernández de Quirós") took possession for the king of Spain all of the
lands he had discovered in Australia del Espiritu Santo (the [New
Hebrides](/wiki/New_Hebrides "New Hebrides")) and those he would discover
"even to the Pole".

[Francis Drake](/wiki/Francis_Drake "Francis Drake"), like Spanish explorers
before him, had speculated that there might be an open channel south of Tierra
del Fuego. When [Willem Schouten](/wiki/Willem_Schouten "Willem Schouten") and
[Jacob Le Maire](/wiki/Jacob_Le_Maire "Jacob Le Maire") discovered the
southern extremity of Tierra del Fuego and named it [Cape
Horn](/wiki/Cape_Horn "Cape Horn") in 1615, they proved that the Tierra del
Fuego archipelago was of small extent and not connected to the southern land,
as previously thought. Subsequently, in 1642, [Abel Tasman](/wiki/Abel_Tasman
"Abel Tasman") showed that even [New Holland
(Australia)](/wiki/New_Holland_\(Australia\) "New Holland \(Australia\)") was
separated by sea from any continuous southern continent.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Edmund_Halley.gif/220px-
Edmund_Halley.gif)](/wiki/File:Edmund_Halley.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Edmund_Halley.gif "Enlarge")

Portrait of [Edmund Halley](/wiki/Edmund_Halley "Edmund Halley") by [Thomas
Murray](/wiki/Thomas_Murray_\(artist\) "Thomas Murray \(artist\)"), c. 1687

### South of the Antarctic
Convergence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: South of the Antarctic Convergence")]

See also: [Anthony de la Roché](/wiki/Anthony_de_la_Roch%C3%A9 "Anthony de la
Roché")

The visit to [South
Georgia](/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands "South Georgia and
the South Sandwich Islands") by [Anthony de la
Roché](/wiki/Anthony_de_la_Roch%C3%A9 "Anthony de la Roché") in 1675 was the
first ever discovery of land south of the [Antarctic
Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic Convergence") i.e. in the
Southern Ocean / [Antarctic](/wiki/Antarctic "Antarctic").[39][40] Soon after
the voyage cartographers started to depict ‘[Roché
Island](/wiki/Anthony_de_la_Roch%C3%A9#Maps_showing_la_Roch.C3.A9.27s_discovery
"Anthony de la Roché")’, honouring the discoverer. [James
Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James Cook") was aware of la Roché's discovery when
surveying and mapping the island in 1775.[41]

[Edmond Halley](/wiki/Edmond_Halley "Edmond Halley")'s voyage in [HMS
_Paramour_](/wiki/HMS_Paramour_\(1694\) "HMS Paramour \(1694\)") for magnetic
investigations in the South Atlantic met the pack ice in [52°
S](/wiki/52nd_parallel_south "52nd parallel south") in January 1700, but that
latitude (he reached 140 mi off the north coast of [South
Georgia](/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands "South Georgia and
the South Sandwich Islands")) was his farthest south. A determined effort on
the part of the French naval officer [Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de
Lozier](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Charles_Bouvet_de_Lozier "Jean-Baptiste Charles
Bouvet de Lozier") to discover the "South Land" – described by a half
legendary "sieur de Gonneyville" – resulted in the discovery of [Bouvet
Island](/wiki/Bouvet_Island "Bouvet Island") in 54°10′ S, and in the
navigation of [48° of longitude](/wiki/48th_meridian_west "48th meridian
west") of ice-cumbered sea nearly in [55° S](/wiki/55th_parallel_south "55th
parallel south") in 1730 .

In 1771, [Yves Joseph Kerguelen](/wiki/Yves-Joseph_de_Kerguelen-Tr%C3%A9marec
"Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec") sailed from [France](/wiki/France
"France") with instructions to proceed south from [Mauritius](/wiki/Mauritius
"Mauritius") in search of "a very large continent." He lighted upon a land in
[50° S](/wiki/50th_parallel_south "50th parallel south") which he called South
France, and believed to be the central mass of the southern continent. He was
sent out again to complete the exploration of the new land, and found it to be
only an inhospitable island which he renamed the Isle of Desolation, but which
[was ultimately named after him](/wiki/Kerguelen_Islands "Kerguelen
Islands").[42]

### South of the Antarctic
Circle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: South of the Antarctic Circle")]

See also: [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James Cook")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Captainjamescookportrait.jpg/220px-
Captainjamescookportrait.jpg)](/wiki/File:Captainjamescookportrait.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Captainjamescookportrait.jpg "Enlarge")

Famous official portrait of Captain [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James
Cook") who proved that waters encompassed the southern latitudes of the globe.
_" He holds his own chart of the Southern Ocean on the table and his right
hand points to the east coast of Australia on it."_[43]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Geography_world_map.jpeg/250px-
Geography_world_map.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Geography_world_map.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Geography_world_map.jpeg "Enlarge")

Map from 1771, showing "Terres Australes" (sic) label without any charted
landmass.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/James_Weddell_Expedition.jpg/250px-
James_Weddell_Expedition.jpg)](/wiki/File:James_Weddell_Expedition.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:James_Weddell_Expedition.jpg "Enlarge")

Painting of [James Weddell](/wiki/James_Weddell "James Weddell")'s second
expedition in 1823, depicting the brig _Jane_ and the cutter _Beaufroy_.

The obsession of the undiscovered continent culminated in the brain of
[Alexander Dalrymple](/wiki/Alexander_Dalrymple "Alexander Dalrymple"), the
brilliant and erratic [hydrographer](/wiki/Hydrography "Hydrography") who was
nominated by the [Royal Society](/wiki/Royal_Society "Royal Society") to
command the [Transit of Venus](/wiki/Transit_of_Venus "Transit of Venus")
expedition to [Tahiti](/wiki/Tahiti "Tahiti") in 1769. The command of the
expedition was given by the admiralty to Captain [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook
"James Cook"). Sailing in 1772 with _Resolution_ , a vessel of 462 tons under
his own command and _Adventure_ of 336 tons under Captain [Tobias
Furneaux](/wiki/Tobias_Furneaux "Tobias Furneaux"), Cook first searched in
vain for [Bouvet Island](/wiki/Bouvet_Island "Bouvet Island"), then sailed for
20 degrees of longitude to the westward in [latitude 58°
S](/wiki/58th_parallel_south "58th parallel south"), and then 30° eastward for
the most part south of [60° S](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel
south"), a lower southern latitude than had ever been voluntarily entered
before by any vessel. On 17 January 1773 the [Antarctic
Circle](/wiki/Antarctic_Circle "Antarctic Circle") was crossed for the first
time in history and the two ships reached 67° 15' S by 39° 35' E, where their
course was stopped by ice.

Cook then turned northward to look for [French Southern and Antarctic
Lands](/wiki/French_Southern_and_Antarctic_Lands "French Southern and
Antarctic Lands"), of the discovery of which he had received news at [Cape
Town](/wiki/Cape_Town "Cape Town"), but from the rough determination of his
longitude by Kerguelen, Cook reached the assigned latitude 10° too far east
and did not see it. He turned south again and was stopped by ice in 61° 52′ S
by 95° E and continued eastward nearly on the parallel of [60°
S](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south") to [147°
E](/wiki/147th_meridian_east "147th meridian east"). On 16 March, the
approaching winter drove him northward for rest to [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") and the tropical islands of the
Pacific. In November 1773, Cook left New Zealand, having parted company with
the _Adventure_ , and reached [60° S](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel
south") by [177° W](/wiki/177th_meridian_west "177th meridian west"), whence
he sailed eastward keeping as far south as the floating ice allowed. The
Antarctic Circle was crossed on 20 December and Cook remained south of it for
three days, being compelled after reaching 67° 31′ S to stand north again in
[135° W](/wiki/135th_meridian_west "135th meridian west").

A long detour to 47° 50′ S served to show that there was no land connection
between New Zealand and [Tierra del Fuego](/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego "Tierra del
Fuego"). Turning south again, Cook crossed the Antarctic Circle for the third
time at 109° 30′ W before his progress was once again blocked by ice four days
later at 71° 10′ S by 106° 54′ W. This point, reached on 30 January 1774, was
the farthest south attained in the 18th century. With a great detour to the
east, almost to the coast of South America, the expedition regained Tahiti for
refreshment. In November 1774, Cook started from New Zealand and crossed the
South Pacific without sighting land between [53°](/wiki/53rd_parallel_south
"53rd parallel south") and [57° S](/wiki/57th_parallel_south "57th parallel
south") to Tierra del Fuego; then, passing Cape Horn on 29 December, he
rediscovered [Roché
Island](/wiki/Anthony_de_la_Roch%C3%A9#Maps_showing_la_Roch.C3.A9.27s_discovery
"Anthony de la Roché") renaming it [Isle of
Georgia](/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands "South Georgia and
the South Sandwich Islands"), and discovered the [South Sandwich
Islands](/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands "South Georgia and
the South Sandwich Islands") (named _Sandwich Land_ by him), the only ice-clad
land he had seen, before crossing the South Atlantic to the Cape of Good Hope
between [55°](/wiki/55th_parallel_south "55th parallel south") and
[60°](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south"). He thereby laid open
the way for future Antarctic exploration by exploding the myth of a habitable
southern continent. Cook's most southerly discovery of land lay on the
temperate side of the [60th parallel](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel
south"), and he convinced himself that if land lay farther south it was
practically inaccessible and without economic value.[42]

Voyagers rounding Cape Horn frequently met with contrary winds and were driven
southward into snowy skies and ice-encumbered seas; but so far as can be
ascertained none of them before 1770 reached the Antarctic Circle, or knew it,
if they did.

In a voyage from 1822 to 1824, [James Weddell](/wiki/James_Weddell "James
Weddell") commanded the 160-ton [brig](/wiki/Brig "Brig") _Jane_ , accompanied
by his second ship _Beaufoy_ captained by Matthew Brisbane. Together they
sailed to the South Orkneys where [sealing](/wiki/Seal_hunting "Seal hunting")
proved disappointing. They turned south in the hope of finding a better
sealing ground. The season was unusually mild and tranquil, and on 20 February
1823 the two ships reached [latitude](/wiki/Latitude "Latitude") 74°15' S and
[longitude](/wiki/Longitude "Longitude") 34°16'45″ W the southernmost position
any ship had ever reached up to that time. A few icebergs were sighted but
there was still no sight of land, leading Weddell to theorize that the sea
continued as far as the South Pole. Another two days' sailing would have
brought him to [Coat's Land](/wiki/Coats_Land "Coats Land") (to the east of
the [Weddell Sea](/wiki/Weddell_Sea "Weddell Sea")) but Weddell decided to
turn back.[44]

### First sighting of
land[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: First sighting of land")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Admiral_Faddey_Faddeyevich_Bellingshausen.jpg/220px-
Admiral_Faddey_Faddeyevich_Bellingshausen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Admiral_Faddey_Faddeyevich_Bellingshausen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Admiral_Faddey_Faddeyevich_Bellingshausen.jpg "Enlarge")

Admiral von Bellingshausen

See also: [William Smith (mariner)](/wiki/William_Smith_\(mariner\) "William
Smith \(mariner\)") and [Fabian von
Bellingshausen](/wiki/Fabian_von_Bellingshausen "Fabian von Bellingshausen")

The first land south of the [parallel 60° south
latitude](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south") was discovered by
the [Englishman](/wiki/English_people "English people") [William
Smith](/wiki/William_Smith_\(mariner\) "William Smith \(mariner\)"), who
sighted [Livingston Island](/wiki/Livingston_Island "Livingston Island") on 19
February 1819. A few months later Smith returned to explore the other islands
of the [South Shetlands](/wiki/South_Shetland_Islands "South Shetland
Islands") archipelago, landed on [King George
Island](/wiki/King_George_Island_\(Antarctica\) "King George Island
\(Antarctica\)"), and claimed the new territories for
[Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland").

In the meantime, the Spanish Navy ship _[San Telmo](/wiki/San_Telmo_\(ship\)
"San Telmo \(ship\)")_ sank in September 1819 when trying to cross Cape Horn.
Parts of her wreckage were found months later by sealers on the north coast of
[Livingston Island](/wiki/Livingston_Island "Livingston Island") ([South
Shetlands](/wiki/South_Shetland_Islands "South Shetland Islands")). It is
unknown if some survivor managed to be the first to set foot on these
Antarctic islands.

The first confirmed sighting of mainland Antarctica cannot be accurately
attributed to one single person. It can, however, be narrowed down to three
individuals. According to various sources,[45][46][47] three men all sighted
the ice shelf or the continent within days or months of each other: von
Bellingshausen, a captain in the Russian Imperial Navy; [Edward
Bransfield](/wiki/Edward_Bransfield "Edward Bransfield"), a captain in the
British navy; and [Nathaniel Palmer](/wiki/Nathaniel_Palmer "Nathaniel
Palmer"), an American sealer out of Stonington, Connecticut. It is certain
that the expedition, led by von Bellingshausen and Lazarev on the ships
_Vostok_ and _Mirny_ , reached a point within 32 km (20 mi) from [Princess
Martha Coast](/wiki/Princess_Martha_Coast "Princess Martha Coast") and
recorded the sight of an ice shelf at [69°21′28″S 2°14′50″W﻿ / ﻿69.35778°S
2.24722°W﻿ / -69.35778;
-2.24722](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Southern_Ocean&params=69_21_28_S_2_14_50_W_)[48]
that became known as the [Fimbul ice shelf](/wiki/Fimbul_Ice_Shelf "Fimbul Ice
Shelf"). On 30 January 1820, Bransfield sighted [Trinity
Peninsula](/wiki/Trinity_Peninsula "Trinity Peninsula"), the northernmost
point of the Antarctic mainland, while Palmer sighted the mainland in the area
south of Trinity Peninsula in November 1820. Von Bellingshausen's expedition
also discovered [Peter I Island](/wiki/Peter_I_Island "Peter I Island") and
[Alexander I Island](/wiki/Alexander_Island "Alexander Island"), the first
islands to be discovered south of the circle.

### Antarctic
expeditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Antarctic expeditions")]

Main article: [List of Antarctic
expeditions](/wiki/List_of_Antarctic_expeditions "List of Antarctic
expeditions")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Vincennes.jpg/220px-
Vincennes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vincennes.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vincennes.jpg "Enlarge")

_USS Vincennes at Disappointment Bay,[Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica
"Antarctica") in early 1840._

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Polar_Regions_exploration_1911.png/300px-
Polar_Regions_exploration_1911.png)](/wiki/File:Polar_Regions_exploration_1911.png)

[](/wiki/File:Polar_Regions_exploration_1911.png "Enlarge")

1911 South Polar Regions exploration map

In December 1839, as part of the [United States Exploring
Expedition](/wiki/United_States_Exploring_Expedition "United States Exploring
Expedition") of 1838–42 conducted by the [United States
Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") (sometimes called "the
Wilkes Expedition"), an expedition sailed from Sydney, Australia, on the
[sloops-of-war](/wiki/Sloop-of-war "Sloop-of-war") [USS
_Vincennes_](/wiki/USS_Vincennes_\(1826\) "USS Vincennes \(1826\)") and [USS
_Peacock_](/wiki/USS_Peacock_\(1828\) "USS Peacock \(1828\)") , the
[brig](/wiki/Brig "Brig") [USS  _Porpoise_](/wiki/USS_Porpoise_\(1836\) "USS
Porpoise \(1836\)") , the [full-rigged ship](/wiki/Full-rigged_ship "Full-
rigged ship") [_Relief_](/wiki/USS_Relief_\(1836\) "USS Relief \(1836\)"), and
two [schooners](/wiki/Schooner "Schooner") [_Sea
Gull_](/wiki/USS_Sea_Gull_\(1838\) "USS Sea Gull \(1838\)") and [USS  _Flying
Fish_](/wiki/USS_Flying_Fish_\(1838\) "USS Flying Fish \(1838\)") . They
sailed into the Antarctic Ocean, as it was then known, and reported the
discovery "of an Antarctic continent west of the [Balleny
Islands](/wiki/Balleny_Islands "Balleny Islands")" on 25 January 1840. That
part of Antarctica was later named "[Wilkes Land](/wiki/Wilkes_Land "Wilkes
Land")", a name it maintains to this day.

Explorer [James Clark Ross](/wiki/James_Clark_Ross "James Clark Ross") passed
through what is now known as the [Ross Sea](/wiki/Ross_Sea "Ross Sea") and
discovered [Ross Island](/wiki/Ross_Island "Ross Island") (both of which were
named for him) in 1841. He sailed along a huge wall of ice that was later
named the [Ross Ice Shelf](/wiki/Ross_Ice_Shelf "Ross Ice Shelf"). [Mount
Erebus](/wiki/Mount_Erebus "Mount Erebus") and [Mount
Terror](/wiki/Mount_Terror_\(Antarctica\) "Mount Terror \(Antarctica\)") are
named after two ships from his expedition: [HMS
_Erebus_](/wiki/HMS_Erebus_\(1826\) "HMS Erebus \(1826\)") and
_[Terror](/wiki/HMS_Terror_\(1813\) "HMS Terror \(1813\)")_.[49]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Endurance_trapped_in_pack_ice.jpg/220px-
Endurance_trapped_in_pack_ice.jpg)](/wiki/File:Endurance_trapped_in_pack_ice.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Endurance_trapped_in_pack_ice.jpg "Enlarge")

Frank Hurley, _As time wore on it became more and more evident that the ship
was doomed_ (The [Endurance](/wiki/Endurance_\(1912_ship\) "Endurance \(1912
ship\)") trapped in pack ice), [National Library of
Australia](/wiki/National_Library_of_Australia "National Library of
Australia").

The [Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition](/wiki/Imperial_Trans-
Antarctic_Expedition "Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition") of 1914, led by
[Ernest Shackleton](/wiki/Ernest_Shackleton "Ernest Shackleton"), set out to
cross the continent via the pole, but their ship, the
[_Endurance_](/wiki/Endurance_\(1912_ship\) "Endurance \(1912 ship\)"), was
trapped and crushed by pack ice before they even landed. The expedition
members survived after an epic journey on sledges over pack ice to [Elephant
Island](/wiki/Elephant_Island "Elephant Island"). Then Shackleton and five
others crossed the Southern Ocean, in an open boat called [_James
Caird_](/wiki/Voyage_of_the_James_Caird "Voyage of the James Caird"), and then
trekked over [South
Georgia](/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands "South Georgia and
the South Sandwich Islands") to raise the alarm at the whaling station
[Grytviken](/wiki/Grytviken "Grytviken").

In 1946, US Navy Rear Admiral [Richard Evelyn Byrd](/wiki/Richard_E._Byrd
"Richard E. Byrd") and more than 4,700 military personnel visited the
Antarctic in an expedition called [Operation
_Highjump_](/wiki/Operation_Highjump "Operation Highjump"). Reported to the
public as a scientific mission, the details were kept secret and it may have
actually been a training or testing mission for the military. The expedition
was, in both military or scientific planning terms, put together very quickly.
The group contained an unusually high amount of military equipment, including
an aircraft carrier, submarines, military support ships, assault troops and
military vehicles. The expedition was planned to last for eight months but was
unexpectedly terminated after only two months. With the exception of some
eccentric entries in Admiral Byrd's diaries, no real explanation for the early
termination has ever been officially given.

Captain [Finn Ronne](/wiki/Finn_Ronne "Finn Ronne"), Byrd's executive officer,
returned to Antarctica with his own expedition in 1947–1948, with Navy
support, three planes, and dogs. Ronne disproved the notion that the continent
was divided in two and established that East and West Antarctica was one
single continent, i.e. that the Weddell Sea and the Ross Sea are not
connected.[50] The expedition explored and mapped large parts of Palmer Land
and the Weddell Sea coastline, and identified the [Ronne Ice
Shelf](/wiki/Filchner-Ronne_Ice_Shelf "Filchner-Ronne Ice Shelf"), named by
Ronne after his wife [Edith "Jackie" Ronne](/wiki/Jackie_Ronne "Jackie
Ronne").[51] Ronne covered 3,600 miles by ski and dog sled—more than any other
explorer in history.[52] The [Ronne Antarctic Research
Expedition](/wiki/Ronne_Antarctic_Research_Expedition "Ronne Antarctic
Research Expedition") discovered and mapped the last unknown coastline in the
world and was the first Antarctic expedition to ever include women.[53]

### Recent
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Recent history")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Glacier_and_Explorer.jpg/220px-
Glacier_and_Explorer.jpg)](/wiki/File:Glacier_and_Explorer.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Glacier_and_Explorer.jpg "Enlarge")

MS _Explorer_ in Antarctica in January 1999. She sank on 23 November 2007
after hitting an [iceberg](/wiki/Iceberg "Iceberg").

The [Antarctic Treaty](/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_System "Antarctic Treaty
System") was signed on 1 December 1959 and came into force on 23 June 1961.
Among other provisions, this treaty limits [military activity in the
Antarctic](/wiki/Military_activity_in_the_Antarctic "Military activity in the
Antarctic") to the support of scientific research.

The first person to sail single-handed to Antarctica was the New Zealander
[David Henry Lewis](/wiki/David_Henry_Lewis "David Henry Lewis"), in 1972, in
a 10-metre steel sloop _Ice Bird_.

A baby, named [Emilio Marcos de Palma](/wiki/Emilio_Palma "Emilio Palma"), was
born near [Hope Bay](/wiki/Hope_Bay "Hope Bay") on 7 January 1978, becoming
the first baby born on the continent. He also was born further south than
anyone in history.[54]

The [MS _Explorer_](/wiki/MV_Explorer_\(1969\) "MV Explorer \(1969\)") was a
[cruise ship](/wiki/Cruise_ship "Cruise ship") operated by the
[Swedish](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") explorer [Lars-Eric Lindblad](/wiki/Lars-
Eric_Lindblad "Lars-Eric Lindblad"). Observers point to the _Explorer 's_ 1969
expeditionary cruise to [Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica") as the
frontrunner for today's sea-based tourism in that region.[55][56] The
_Explorer_ was the first cruise ship used specifically to sail the icy waters
of the Antarctic Ocean and the first to sink there[57] when she struck an
unidentified submerged object on 23 November 2007, reported to be ice, which
caused a 10 by 4 inches (25 by 10 cm) gash in the hull.[58] The _Explorer_ was
abandoned in the early hours of 23 November 2007 after taking on water near
the [South Shetland Islands](/wiki/South_Shetland_Islands "South Shetland
Islands") in the Southern Ocean, an area which is usually stormy but was calm
at the time.[59] The _Explorer_ was confirmed by the [Chilean
Navy](/wiki/Chilean_Navy "Chilean Navy") to have sunk at approximately
position: 62° 24′ South, 57° 16′ West,[60] in roughly 600 m of water.[61]

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Geography")]

See also: [List of Antarctic and subantarctic
islands](/wiki/List_of_Antarctic_and_subantarctic_islands "List of Antarctic
and subantarctic islands")

The Southern Ocean, geologically the youngest of the oceans, was formed when
Antarctica and [South America](/wiki/South_America "South America") moved
apart, opening the [Drake Passage](/wiki/Drake_Passage "Drake Passage"),
roughly 30 million years ago. The separation of the continents allowed the
formation of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current.

With a northern limit at [60°S](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel
south"), the Southern Ocean differs from the other oceans in that its largest
boundary, the northern boundary, does not abut a landmass (as it did with the
first edition of _Limits of Oceans and Seas_). Instead, the northern limit is
with the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans.

One reason for considering it as a separate ocean stems from the fact that
much of the water of the Southern Ocean differs from the water in the other
oceans. Water gets transported around the Southern Ocean fairly rapidly
because of the [Antarctic Circumpolar
Current](/wiki/Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current "Antarctic Circumpolar Current")
which circulates around Antarctica. Water in the Southern Ocean south of, for
example, New Zealand, resembles the water in the Southern Ocean south of South
America more closely than it resembles the water in the Pacific Ocean.

The Southern Ocean has typical depths of between 4,000 and 5,000 m (13,000 and
16,000 ft) over most of its extent with only limited areas of shallow water.
The Southern Ocean's greatest depth of 7,236 m (23,740 ft) occurs at the
southern end of the [South Sandwich Trench](/wiki/South_Sandwich_Trench "South
Sandwich Trench"), at 60°00'S, 024°W. The [Antarctic continental
shelf](/wiki/Antarctic_continental_shelf "Antarctic continental shelf")
appears generally narrow and unusually deep, its edge lying at depths up to
800 m (2,600 ft), compared to a global mean of 133 m (436 ft).

[Equinox](/wiki/Equinox "Equinox") to equinox in line with the sun's seasonal
influence, the Antarctic ice pack fluctuates from an average minimum of 2.6
million square kilometres (1.0×10~~^~~ 6 sq mi) in March to about 18.8 million
square kilometres (7.3×10~~^~~ 6 sq mi) in September, more than a sevenfold
increase in area.

### Sub-divisions of the Southern
Ocean[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Sub-divisions of the Southern Ocean")]

Sub-divisions of oceans are geographical features such as "seas", "straits",
"bays", "channels", and "gulfs". There are many sub-divisions of the Southern
Ocean defined in the never-approved 2002 draft fourth edition of the IHO
publication _Limits of Oceans and Seas_. In clockwise order these include
(with IHO sub-division chartlet numbers in parenthesis) the [Weddell
Sea](/wiki/Weddell_Sea "Weddell Sea") (10.1), the [Lazarev
Sea](/wiki/Lazarev_Sea "Lazarev Sea") (10.2), the [Riiser-Larsen
Sea](/wiki/Riiser-Larsen_Sea "Riiser-Larsen Sea") (10.3), the [Cosmonauts
Sea](/wiki/Cosmonauts_Sea "Cosmonauts Sea") (10.4), the [Cooperation
Sea](/wiki/Cooperation_Sea "Cooperation Sea") (10.5), the [Davis
Sea](/wiki/Davis_Sea "Davis Sea") (10.6), [Tryoshnikova Gulf](/wiki/Davis_Sea
"Davis Sea") (10.6.1), the [Mawson Sea](/wiki/Mawson_Sea "Mawson Sea") (10.7),
the [Dumont D'Urville Sea](/wiki/D%27Urville_Sea "D'Urville Sea") (10.8), the
[Somov Sea](/wiki/Somov_Sea "Somov Sea") (10.9), the [Ross Sea](/wiki/Ross_Sea
"Ross Sea") (10.10), [McMurdo Sound](/wiki/McMurdo_Sound "McMurdo Sound")
(10.10.1), the [Amundsen Sea](/wiki/Amundsen_Sea "Amundsen Sea") (10.11), the
[Bellingshausen Sea](/wiki/Bellingshausen_Sea "Bellingshausen Sea") (10.12),
part of the [Drake Passage](/wiki/Drake_Passage "Drake Passage") (10.13),
[Bransfield Strait](/wiki/Bransfield_Strait "Bransfield Strait") (10.14) and
part of the [Scotia Sea](/wiki/Scotia_Sea "Scotia Sea") (4.2).[29][note
7][note 8] A number of these such as the 2002 Russian-proposed "Consmonauts
Sea", "Cooperation Sea", and "Somov (mid-1950s Russian polar explorer) Sea"
are not included in the 1953 IHO document which remains currently in
force,[27] because they received their names largely originated from 1962
onward. Leading geographic authorities and atlases do not use these latter
three names, including the 2014 10th edition World Atlas from the United
States' [National Geographic Society](/wiki/National_Geographic_Society
"National Geographic Society") and the 2014 12th edition of the British [Times
Atlas of the World](/wiki/Times_Atlas_of_the_World "Times Atlas of the
World"), but Soviet and Russian-issued maps do.[62][63]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/McMurdo_Sound_Glacier-
iv.jpg/220px-McMurdo_Sound_Glacier-iv.jpg)](/wiki/File:McMurdo_Sound_Glacier-
iv.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:McMurdo_Sound_Glacier-iv.jpg "Enlarge")

An iceberg being pushed out of a shipping lane [USS  _Burton Island_
(AGB-1)](/wiki/USS_Burton_Island_\(AGB-1\) "USS Burton Island \(AGB-1\)"),
[USS  _Atka_ (AGB-3)](/wiki/USS_Atka_\(AGB-3\) "USS Atka \(AGB-3\)"), and [USS

### Natural
resources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Natural resources")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Manganknolle.jpg/220px-
Manganknolle.jpg)](/wiki/File:Manganknolle.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Manganknolle.jpg "Enlarge")

Manganese nodule

The Southern Ocean probably contains large, and possibly giant,
[oil](/wiki/Petroleum "Petroleum") and [gas](/wiki/Natural_gas "Natural gas")
fields on the [continental margin](/wiki/Continental_margin "Continental
margin"). [Placer deposits](/wiki/Placer_deposit "Placer deposit"),
accumulation of valuable minerals such as gold, formed by gravity separation
during sedimentary processes are also expected to exist in the Southern
Ocean.[6]

[Manganese nodules](/wiki/Manganese_nodules "Manganese nodules") are expected
to exist in the Southern Ocean. Manganese nodules are rock
[concretions](/wiki/Concretion "Concretion") on the [sea](/wiki/Sea "Sea")
bottom formed of concentric layers of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") and
[manganese](/wiki/Manganese "Manganese") [hydroxides](/wiki/Hydroxide
"Hydroxide") around a core. The core may be microscopically small and is
sometimes completely transformed into manganese minerals by
[crystallization](/wiki/Crystallization "Crystallization"). Interest in the
potential exploitation of polymetallic nodules generated a great deal of
activity among prospective mining consortia in the 1960s and 1970s.[6]

The [icebergs](/wiki/Iceberg "Iceberg") that form each year around in the
Southern Ocean hold enough [fresh water](/wiki/Fresh_water "Fresh water") to
meet the needs of every person on Earth for several months. For several
decades there have been proposals, none yet to be feasible or successful, to
tow Southern Ocean icebergs to more arid northern regions (such as Australia)
where they can be harvested.[64]

### Natural
hazards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Natural hazards")]

[Icebergs](/wiki/Iceberg "Iceberg") can occur at any time of year throughout
the ocean. Some may have drafts up to several hundred meters; smaller
icebergs, iceberg fragments and sea-ice (generally 0.5 to 1 m thick) also pose
problems for ships. The deep continental shelf has a floor of glacial deposits
varying widely over short distances.

Sailors know latitudes from [40](/wiki/40th_parallel_south "40th parallel
south") to [70 degrees south](/wiki/70th_parallel_south "70th parallel south")
as the "[Roaring Forties](/wiki/Roaring_Forties "Roaring Forties")", "Furious
Fifties" and "Shrieking Sixties" due to high winds and large waves that form
as winds blow around the entire globe unimpeded by any land-mass. Icebergs,
especially in May to October, make the area even more dangerous. The
remoteness of the region makes sources of search and rescue scarce.

## Physical
oceanography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Physical oceanography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current.jpg/250px-
Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current.jpg)](/wiki/File:Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current.jpg "Enlarge")

The Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) is the strongest current system in the
world oceans, linking the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific basins.

### Antarctic Circumpolar Current and Antarctic
Convergence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Antarctic Circumpolar Current and Antarctic Convergence")]

The [Antarctic Circumpolar Current](/wiki/Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current
"Antarctic Circumpolar Current") moves perpetually eastward — chasing and
joining itself, and at 21,000 km (13,000 mi) in length — it comprises the
world's longest ocean current, transporting 130 million cubic metres per
second (4.6×10~~^~~ 9 cu ft/s) of water – 100 times the flow of all the
world's rivers.

Several processes operate along the coast of Antarctica to produce, in the
Southern Ocean, types of [water masses](/wiki/Water_mass "Water mass") not
produced elsewhere in the oceans of the [Southern
Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern Hemisphere"). One of these is
the [Antarctic Bottom Water](/wiki/Antarctic_Bottom_Water "Antarctic Bottom
Water"), a very cold, highly saline, dense water that forms under [sea
ice](/wiki/Sea_ice "Sea ice").

Associated with the Circumpolar Current is the [Antarctic
Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic Convergence") encircling
Antarctica, where cold northward-flowing Antarctic waters meet the relatively
warmer waters of the [subantarctic](/wiki/Subantarctic "Subantarctic"),
Antarctic waters predominantly sink beneath subantarctic waters, while
associated zones of mixing and [upwelling](/wiki/Upwelling "Upwelling") create
a zone very high in nutrients. These nurture high levels of
[phytoplankton](/wiki/Phytoplankton "Phytoplankton") with associated copepods
and [Antarctic krill](/wiki/Antarctic_krill "Antarctic krill"), and resultant
foodchains supporting fish, whales, seals, penguins, albatrosses and a wealth
of other species.[65]

The Antarctic Convergence is considered to be the best natural definition of
the northern extent of the Southern Ocean.[6]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Antarctic_bottom_water.svg/250px-
Antarctic_bottom_water.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Antarctic_bottom_water.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Antarctic_bottom_water.svg "Enlarge")

Upwelling in the Southern Ocean

### Upwelling[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Upwelling")]

Large-scale [upwelling](/wiki/Upwelling "Upwelling") is found in the Southern
Ocean. Strong westerly (eastward) winds blow around
[Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica"), driving a significant flow of
water northwards. This is actually a type of coastal upwelling. Since there
are no continents in a band of open latitudes between [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America") and the tip of the [Antarctic
Peninsula](/wiki/Antarctic_Peninsula "Antarctic Peninsula"), some of this
water is drawn up from great depths. In many numerical models and
observational syntheses, the Southern Ocean upwelling represents the primary
means by which deep dense water is brought to the surface. Shallower, wind-
driven upwelling is also found off the west coasts of North and South America,
northwest and southwest Africa, and southwest and [southeast
Australia](/wiki/Great_South_Australian_Coastal_Upwelling_System "Great South
Australian Coastal Upwelling System"), all associated with oceanic subtropical
high pressure circulations.

Some models of the ocean circulation suggest that broad-scale upwelling occurs
in the tropics, as pressure driven flows converge water toward the low
latitudes where it is diffusively warmed from above. The required diffusion
coefficients, however, appear to be larger than are observed in the real
ocean. Nonetheless, some diffusive upwelling does probably occur.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Antarctic_frontal-
system_hg.png/250px-Antarctic_frontal-
system_hg.png)](/wiki/File:Antarctic_frontal-system_hg.png)

[](/wiki/File:Antarctic_frontal-system_hg.png "Enlarge")

Location of the Southern Ocean gyres.

### Ross and Weddell
Gyres[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Ross and Weddell Gyres")]

The [Ross Gyre](/wiki/Ross_Gyre "Ross Gyre") and [Weddell
Gyre](/wiki/Weddell_Gyre "Weddell Gyre") are two [gyres](/wiki/Oceanic_gyre
"Oceanic gyre") that exist within the Southern Ocean. The gyres are located in
the [Ross Sea](/wiki/Ross_Sea "Ross Sea") and [Weddell Sea](/wiki/Weddell_Sea
"Weddell Sea") respectively, and both rotate clockwise. The gyres are formed
by interactions between the [Antarctic Circumpolar
Current](/wiki/Antarctic_Circumpolar_Current "Antarctic Circumpolar Current")
and the [Antarctic Continental Shelf](/wiki/Antarctic_Continental_Shelf
"Antarctic Continental Shelf").

[Sea ice](/wiki/Sea_ice "Sea ice") has been noted to persist in the central
area of the Ross Gyre.[66] There is some evidence that [global
warming](/wiki/Global_warming "Global warming") has resulted in some decrease
of the [salinity](/wiki/Salinity "Salinity") of the waters of the Ross Gyre
since the 1950s.[67]

Due to the [Coriolis effect](/wiki/Coriolis_effect "Coriolis effect") acting
to the left in the [Southern Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern
Hemisphere") and the resulting [Ekman transport](/wiki/Ekman_transport "Ekman
transport") away from the centres of the Weddell Gyre, these regions are very
productive due to upwelling of cold, nutrient rich water.

## Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Climate")]

Sea temperatures vary from about −2 to 10 [°C](/wiki/Celsius "Celsius") (28 to
50 [°F](/wiki/Fahrenheit "Fahrenheit")). Cyclonic storms travel eastward
around the continent and frequently become intense because of the temperature
contrast between ice and [open ocean](/wiki/Pelagic_zone "Pelagic zone"). The
ocean-area from about [latitude 40 south](/wiki/40th_parallel_south "40th
parallel south") to the Antarctic Circle has the strongest average winds found
anywhere on Earth.[68] In winter the ocean freezes outward to [65 degrees
south latitude](/wiki/65th_parallel_south "65th parallel south") in the
Pacific sector and [55 degrees south latitude](/wiki/55th_parallel_south "55th
parallel south") in the Atlantic sector, lowering surface temperatures well
below 0 degrees Celsius. At some coastal points, however, persistent intense
drainage winds from the interior keep the shoreline ice-free throughout the
winter.

Southern_Ocean-2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Southern_Ocean-2.JPG "Clouds over Southern
Ocean with Continent labels.")
