### Animals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Animals")]

A variety of marine animals exist and rely, directly or indirectly, on the
phytoplankton in the Southern Ocean. Antarctic sea life includes
[penguins](/wiki/Penguin "Penguin"), [blue whales](/wiki/Blue_whale "Blue
whale"), [orcas](/wiki/Killer_whale "Killer whale"), [colossal
squids](/wiki/Colossal_squid "Colossal squid") and [fur seals](/wiki/Fur_seal
"Fur seal"). The [emperor penguin](/wiki/Emperor_penguin "Emperor penguin") is
the only penguin that breeds during the winter in Antarctica, while the
[Adélie penguin](/wiki/Ad%C3%A9lie_penguin "Adélie penguin") breeds farther
south than any other penguin. The [rockhopper
penguin](/wiki/Rockhopper_penguin "Rockhopper penguin") has distinctive
feathers around the eyes, giving the appearance of elaborate eyelashes. [King
penguins](/wiki/King_penguin "King penguin"), [chinstrap
penguins](/wiki/Chinstrap_penguin "Chinstrap penguin"), and [gentoo
penguins](/wiki/Gentoo_penguin "Gentoo penguin") also breed in the Antarctic.

The [Antarctic fur seal](/wiki/Antarctic_fur_seal "Antarctic fur seal") was
very heavily hunted in the 18th and 19th centuries for its pelt by sealers
from the United States and the United Kingdom. The [Weddell
seal](/wiki/Weddell_seal "Weddell seal"), a "[true seal](/wiki/True_seal "True
seal")", is named after [Sir James Weddell](/wiki/James_Weddell "James
Weddell"), commander of British sealing expeditions in the [Weddell
Sea](/wiki/Weddell_Sea "Weddell Sea"). [Antarctic krill](/wiki/Antarctic_krill
"Antarctic krill"), which congregates in large
[schools](/wiki/Shoaling_and_schooling "Shoaling and schooling"), is the
[keystone species](/wiki/Keystone_species "Keystone species") of the
[ecosystem](/wiki/Ecosystem "Ecosystem") of the Southern Ocean, and is an
important food organism for whales, seals, [leopard seals](/wiki/Leopard_seal
"Leopard seal"), fur seals, [squid](/wiki/Squid "Squid"),
[icefish](/wiki/Notothenioidei "Notothenioidei"), penguins,
[albatrosses](/wiki/Albatross "Albatross") and many other birds.[69]

The [benthic](/wiki/Benthic "Benthic") communities of the seafloor are diverse
and dense, with up to 155,000 animals found in 1 square metre (10.8 sq ft). As
the seafloor environment is very similar all around the Antarctic, hundreds of
species can be found all the way around the mainland, which is a uniquely wide
distribution for such a large community. [Deep-sea gigantism](/wiki/Deep-
sea_gigantism "Deep-sea gigantism") is common among these animals.[70]

A census of sea life carried out during the [International Polar
Year](/wiki/International_Polar_Year "International Polar Year") and which
involved some 500 researchers was released in 2010. The research is part of
the global [Census of Marine Life](/wiki/Census_of_Marine_Life "Census of
Marine Life") (CoML) and has disclosed some remarkable findings. More than 235
marine organisms live in both polar regions, having bridged the gap of 12,000
km (7,456 mi). Large animals such as some cetaceans and birds make the round
trip annually. More surprising are small forms of life such as mudworms, [sea
cucumbers](/wiki/Sea_cucumber "Sea cucumber") and free-swimming snails found
in both polar oceans. Various factors may aid in their distribution – fairly
uniform temperatures of the deep ocean at the poles and the equator which
differ by no more than 5 °C, and the major current systems or marine [conveyor
belt](/wiki/Thermohaline_circulation "Thermohaline circulation") which
transport egg and larva stages.[71]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Wonder_albat.jpg/220px-
Wonder_albat.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wonder_albat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wonder_albat.jpg "Enlarge")

A [wandering albatross](/wiki/Wandering_albatross "Wandering albatross")
(_Diomedea exulans_) on [South Georgia](/wiki/South_Georgia_Island "South
Georgia Island")

### Birds[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Birds")]

See also: [List of birds of Antarctica](/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Antarctica
"List of birds of Antarctica")

The rocky shores of mainland Antarctica and its offshore islands provide
nesting space for over 100 million birds every spring. These nesters include
species of [albatrosses](/wiki/Albatross "Albatross"), [petrels](/wiki/Petrel
"Petrel"), [skuas](/wiki/Skua "Skua"), [gulls](/wiki/Gull "Gull") and
[terns](/wiki/Tern "Tern").[72] The insectivorous [South Georgia
pipit](/wiki/South_Georgia_pipit "South Georgia pipit") is
[endemic](/wiki/Endemism "Endemism") to [South
Georgia](/wiki/South_Georgia_Island "South Georgia Island") and some smaller
surrounding islands. Freshwater ducks inhabit South Georgia and the [Kerguelen
Islands](/wiki/Kerguelen_Islands "Kerguelen Islands").[73]

The flightless [penguins](/wiki/Penguin "Penguin") are all located in the
[Southern Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern Hemisphere"), with
the greatest concentration located on and around Antarctica. Four of the 18
penguin species live and breed on the mainland and its close offshore islands.
Another four species live on the subantarctic islands.[74] [Emperor
penguins](/wiki/Emperor_penguins "Emperor penguins") have four overlapping
layers of feathers, keeping them warm. They are the only Antarctic animal to
breed during the winter.[75]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Icefishuk.jpg/220px-
Icefishuk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Icefishuk.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Icefishuk.jpg "Enlarge")

Fish of the [Notothenioidei](/wiki/Notothenioidei "Notothenioidei") suborder,
such as this young icefish, are mostly endemic to Antarctica.

### Fish[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Fish")]

There are very few species of fish in the Southern Ocean. The
[Channichthyidae](/wiki/Channichthyidae "Channichthyidae") family, also known
as white-blooded fish, are only found in the Southern Ocean. They lack
[hemoglobin](/wiki/Hemoglobin "Hemoglobin") in their blood, resulting in their
blood being colourless. One Channichthyidae species, the [mackerel
icefish](/wiki/Mackerel_icefish "Mackerel icefish") (_Champsocephalus
gunnari_), was once the most common fish in coastal waters less than 400
metres (1,312 ft) deep, but was [overfished](/wiki/Overfishing "Overfishing")
in the 1970s and 1980s. Schools of icefish spend the day at the seafloor and
the night higher in the [water column](/wiki/Water_column "Water column")
eating plankton and smaller fish.[76]

There are two species from the _[Dissostichus](/wiki/Dissostichus
"Dissostichus")_ genus, the [Antarctic toothfish](/wiki/Antarctic_toothfish
"Antarctic toothfish") (_Dissostichus mawsoni_) and the [Patagonian
toothfish](/wiki/Patagonian_toothfish "Patagonian toothfish") (_Dissostichus
eleginoides_). These two species live on the seafloor 100–3,000 metres
(328–9,843 ft) deep, and can grow to around 2 metres (7 ft) long weighing up
to 100 kilograms (220 lb), living up to 45 years. The Antarctic toothfish
lives close to the Antarctic mainland, whereas the Patagonian toothfish lives
in the relatively warmer subantarctic waters. Due to the low water
temperatures around the mainland, the Antarctic toothfish has [antifreeze
proteins](/wiki/Antifreeze_protein "Antifreeze protein") in its blood and
tissues. Toothfish are commercially fished, and overfishing has reduced
toothfish populations.[76]

Another abundant fish group is the _[Notothenia](/wiki/Notothenia
"Notothenia")_ genus, which like the Antarctic toothfish have antifreeze in
their bodies.[76]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Phoque_de_Weddell_-
_Weddell_Seal.jpg/220px-Phoque_de_Weddell_-
_Weddell_Seal.jpg)](/wiki/File:Phoque_de_Weddell_-_Weddell_Seal.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Phoque_de_Weddell_-_Weddell_Seal.jpg "Enlarge")

[Weddell seals](/wiki/Weddell_seal "Weddell seal") (_Leptonychotes weddellii_)
are the most southerly of Antarctic mammals.

### Mammals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Mammals")]

See also: [List of mammals of Antarctica](/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Antarctica
"List of mammals of Antarctica")

Seven [pinniped](/wiki/Pinniped "Pinniped") species inhabit Antarctica. The
largest, the [elephant seal](/wiki/Elephant_seal "Elephant seal") (_Mirounga
leonina_), can reach up to 4,000 kilograms (8,818 lb), while females of the
smallest, the [Antarctic fur seal](/wiki/Antarctic_fur_seal "Antarctic fur
seal") (_Arctocephalus gazella_), reach only 150 kilograms (331 lb). These two
species live north of the sea ice, and breed in
[harems](/wiki/Harem_\(zoology\) "Harem \(zoology\)") on beaches. The other
four species can live on the sea ice. [Crabeater seals](/wiki/Crabeater_seal
"Crabeater seal") (_Lobodon carcinophagus_) and [Weddell
seals](/wiki/Weddell_seal "Weddell seal") (_Leptonychotes weddellii_) form
breeding colonies, whereas [leopard seals](/wiki/Leopard_seal "Leopard seal")
(_Hydrurga leptonyx_) and [Ross seals](/wiki/Ross_seal "Ross seal")
(_Ommatophoca rossii_) live solitary lives. Although these species hunt
underwater, they breed on land or ice and spend a great deal of time there, as
they have no terrestrial predators.[77]

The four species that inhabit sea ice are thought to make up 50% of the total
biomass of the world's seals.[78] Crabeater seals have a population of around
15 million, making them one of the most numerous large animals on the
planet.[79] The [New Zealand sea lion](/wiki/New_Zealand_sea_lion "New Zealand
sea lion") (_Phocarctos hookeri_), one of the rarest and most localised
pinnipeds, breeds almost exclusively on the subantarctic [Auckland
Islands](/wiki/Auckland_Islands "Auckland Islands"), although historically it
had a wider range.[80] Out of all permanent mammalian residents, the Weddell
seals live the furthest south.[81]

There are 10 [cetacean](/wiki/Cetacea "Cetacea") species found in the Southern
Ocean; six [baleen whales](/wiki/Baleen_whale "Baleen whale"), and four
[toothed whales](/wiki/Toothed_whale "Toothed whale"). The largest of these,
the [blue whale](/wiki/Blue_whale "Blue whale") (_Balaenoptera musculus_),
grows to 24 metres (79 ft) long weighing 84 tonnes. Many of these species are
[migratory](/wiki/Animal_migration "Animal migration"), and travel to
[tropical](/wiki/Tropics "Tropics") waters during the Antarctic winter.[82]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Antarctic_krill_%28Euphausia_superba%29.jpg/220px-
Antarctic_krill_%28Euphausia_superba%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Antarctic_krill_\(Euphausia_superba\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Antarctic_krill_\(Euphausia_superba\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Antarctic krill](/wiki/Antarctic_krill "Antarctic krill") (_Euphausia
superba_) are a [keystone species](/wiki/Keystone_species "Keystone species")
of the food web.

### Arthropods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Arthropods")]

Five species of [krill](/wiki/Krill "Krill"), small free-swimming
[crustaceans](/wiki/Crustacean "Crustacean"), are found in the Southern
Ocean.[83] The [Antarctic krill](/wiki/Antarctic_krill "Antarctic krill")
(_Euphausia superba_) is one of the most abundant animal species on earth,
with a [biomass](/wiki/Biomass "Biomass") of around 500 million tonnes. Each
individual is 6 centimetres (2.4 in) long and weighs over 1 gram (0.035
oz).[84] The swarms that form can stretch for kilometres, with up to 30,000
individuals per 1 cubic metre (35 cu ft), turning the water red.[83] Swarms
usually remain in deep water during the day, ascending during the night to
feed on [plankton](/wiki/Plankton "Plankton"). Many larger animals depend on
krill for their own survival.[84] During the winter when food is scarce, adult
Antarctic krill can revert to a smaller juvenile stage, using their own body
as nutrition.[83]

Many benthic crustaceans have a non-seasonal breeding cycle, and some raise
their young in a [brood pouch](/wiki/Brood_pouch_\(Peracarida\) "Brood pouch
\(Peracarida\)"). _[Glyptonotus antarcticus](/wiki/Glyptonotus_antarcticus
"Glyptonotus antarcticus")_ is an unusually large benthic
[isopod](/wiki/Isopod "Isopod"), reaching 20 centimetres (8 in) in length
weighing 70 grams (2.47 oz). [Amphipods](/wiki/Amphipoda "Amphipoda") are
abundant in soft sediments, eating a range of items, from [algae](/wiki/Algae
"Algae") to other animals.[70]

Slow moving [sea spiders](/wiki/Sea_spider "Sea spider") are common, sometimes
growing as large as a human hand. They feed on the [corals](/wiki/Coral
"Coral"), [sponges](/wiki/Sponge "Sponge"), and [bryozoans](/wiki/Bryozoa
"Bryozoa") that litter the seabed.[70]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Onykia_ingens_384_mm_ML.jpg/220px-
Onykia_ingens_384_mm_ML.jpg)](/wiki/File:Onykia_ingens_384_mm_ML.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Onykia_ingens_384_mm_ML.jpg "Enlarge")

A female [warty squid](/wiki/Moroteuthis_ingens "Moroteuthis ingens")
(_Moroteuthis ingens_)

###
Invertebrates[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Invertebrates")]

Many [aquatic](/wiki/Aquatic_animals "Aquatic animals")
[molluscs](/wiki/Mollusc "Mollusc") are present in Antarctica.
[Bivalves](/wiki/Bivalves "Bivalves") such as _[Adamussium
colbecki](/wiki/Adamussium_colbecki "Adamussium colbecki")_ move around on the
seafloor, while others such as _[Laternula
elliptica](/wiki/Laternula_elliptica "Laternula elliptica")_ live in burrows
[filtering](/wiki/Filter_feeder "Filter feeder") the water above.[70] There
are around 70 [cephalopod](/wiki/Cephalopod "Cephalopod") species in the
Southern Ocean, the largest of which is the [giant squid](/wiki/Giant_squid
"Giant squid") (_Architeuthis_ sp.), which at 15 metres (49 ft) is the largest
invertebrate in the world. [Squid](/wiki/Squid "Squid") makes up the entire
diet of some animals, such as [grey-headed albatrosses](/wiki/Grey-
headed_albatross "Grey-headed albatross") and [sperm whales](/wiki/Sperm_whale
"Sperm whale"), and the [warty squid](/wiki/Moroteuthis_ingens "Moroteuthis
ingens") (_Moroteuthis ingens_) is one of the subantarctic's most preyed upon
species by vertebrates.[85]

The [sea urchin](/wiki/Sea_urchin "Sea urchin") genus
_[Abatus](/w/index.php?title=Abatus&action=edit&redlink=1 "Abatus \(page does
not exist\)")_ burrow through the sediment eating the nutrients they find in
it.[70] Two species of [salps](/wiki/Salp "Salp") are common in Antarctic
waters, _[Salpa
thompsoni](/w/index.php?title=Salpa_thompsoni&action=edit&redlink=1 "Salpa
thompsoni \(page does not exist\)")_ and _[Ihlea
racovitzai](/w/index.php?title=Ihlea_racovitzai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ihlea
racovitzai \(page does not exist\)")_. _Salpa thompsoni_ is found in ice-free
areas, whereas _Ihlea racovitzai_ is found in the high latitude areas near
ice. Due to their low nutritional value, they are normally only eaten by fish,
with larger animals such as birds and marine mammals only eating them when
other food is scarce.[86]

Antarctic [sponges](/wiki/Sponge "Sponge") are long lived, and sensitive to
environmental changes due to the specificity of the
[symbiotic](/wiki/Symbiosis "Symbiosis") microbial communities within them. As
a result, they function as indicators of environmental health.[87]

## Environment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Environment")]

### Current
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=31 "Edit
section: Current issues")]

Increased solar [ultraviolet radiation](/wiki/Ultraviolet "Ultraviolet")
resulting from the Antarctic [ozone hole](/wiki/Ozone_hole "Ozone hole") has
reduced marine primary productivity ([phytoplankton](/wiki/Phytoplankton
"Phytoplankton")) by as much as 15% and has started damaging the
[DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA") of some fish.[88] Illegal, unreported, and unregulated
fishing, especially the landing of an estimated five to six times more
[Patagonian toothfish](/wiki/Patagonian_toothfish "Patagonian toothfish") than
the regulated fishery, likely affects the sustainability of the stock. Long-
line fishing for toothfish causes a high incidence of seabird mortality.

### International
agreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: International agreements")]

All international agreements regarding the world's oceans apply to the
Southern Ocean. In addition, it is subject to these agreements specific to the
region:

  * The _[Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary](/wiki/Southern_Ocean_Whale_Sanctuary "Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary")_ of the [International Whaling Commission](/wiki/International_Whaling_Commission "International Whaling Commission") (IWC) prohibits commercial [whaling](/wiki/Whaling "Whaling") south of [40 degrees south](/wiki/40th_parallel_south "40th parallel south") (south of [60 degrees south](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south") between [50 degrees](/wiki/50th_meridian_west "50th meridian west") and [130 degrees west](/wiki/130th_meridian_west "130th meridian west")). [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan") regularly does not recognize this provision, because the sanctuary violates IWC charter. Since the scope of the sanctuary is limited to commercial whaling, in regard to its whaling permit and whaling for scientific research, a Japanese fleet carried out an annual whale-hunt in the region. On 31 March 2014, the [International Court of Justice](/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice "International Court of Justice") ruled that Japan's whaling program, which Japan has long claimed is for scientific purposes, was a cloak for commercial whaling, and no further permits would be granted.
  * _[Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals](/wiki/Convention_for_the_Conservation_of_Antarctic_Seals "Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals")_ is part of the _[Antarctic Treaty System](/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_System "Antarctic Treaty System")_. It was signed at the conclusion of a multilateral conference in London on 11 February 1972.[89]
  * _[Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources](/wiki/Convention_for_the_Conservation_of_Antarctic_Marine_Living_Resources "Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources")_ (CCAMLR) is part of the _[Antarctic Treaty System](/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_System "Antarctic Treaty System")_. The Convention was entered into force on 7 April 1982 and has its goal is to preserve [marine life](/wiki/Marine_life "Marine life") and environmental integrity in and near [Antarctica](/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica"). It was established in large part to concerns that an increase in [krill](/wiki/Krill "Krill") catches in the Southern Ocean could have a serious impact on populations of other marine life which are dependent upon krill for food.[90]

Many nations prohibit the exploration for and the exploitation of
[mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") resources south of the fluctuating
[Antarctic Convergence](/wiki/Antarctic_Convergence "Antarctic
Convergence"),[91] which lies in the middle of the Antarctic Circumpolar
Current and serves as the dividing line between the very cold polar surface
waters to the south and the warmer waters to the north. The [Antarctic
Treaty](/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty "Antarctic Treaty") covers the portion of the
globe south of [sixty degrees south](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel
south"),[92] it prohibits new claims to Antarctica.[93]

The _Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources_
applies to the area south of 60° South latitude as well as the areas further
north up to the limit of the Antarctic Convergence.[94]

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Economy")]

Between 1 July 1998 and 30 June 1999, fisheries landed 119,898
[tonnes](/wiki/Tonne "Tonne"), of which 85% consisted of [krill](/wiki/Krill
"Krill") and 14% of [Patagonian toothfish](/wiki/Patagonian_toothfish
"Patagonian toothfish"). International agreements came into force in late 1999
to reduce illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing, which in the 1998–99
season landed five to six times more Patagonian toothfish than the regulated
fishery.

## Ports and
harbors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Southern_Ocean&action=edit&section=34 "Edit
section: Ports and harbors")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/USNS_Southern_Cross_at_the_ice_pier_in_1983.jpg/300px-
USNS_Southern_Cross_at_the_ice_pier_in_1983.jpg)](/wiki/File:USNS_Southern_Cross_at_the_ice_pier_in_1983.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USNS_Southern_Cross_at_the_ice_pier_in_1983.jpg "Enlarge")

Severe cracks in an [ice pier](/wiki/Ice_pier "Ice pier") in use for four
seasons at [McMurdo Station](/wiki/McMurdo_Station "McMurdo Station") slowed
cargo operations in 1983 and proved a safety hazard.

Major operational ports include: [Rothera
Station](/wiki/Rothera_Research_Station "Rothera Research Station"), [Palmer
Station](/wiki/Palmer_Station "Palmer Station"), [Villa Las
Estrellas](/wiki/Villa_Las_Estrellas "Villa Las Estrellas"), [Esperanza
Base](/wiki/Esperanza_Base "Esperanza Base"), [Mawson
Station](/wiki/Mawson_Station "Mawson Station"), [McMurdo
Station](/wiki/McMurdo_Station "McMurdo Station"), and offshore anchorages in
Antarctica.

Few ports or harbors exist on the southern (Antarctic) coast of the Southern
Ocean, since ice conditions limit use of most shores to short periods in
midsummer; even then some require [icebreaker](/wiki/Icebreaker "Icebreaker")
escort for access. Most Antarctic ports are operated by government research
stations and, except in an emergency, remain closed to commercial or private
vessels; vessels in any port south of [60 degrees
south](/wiki/60th_parallel_south "60th parallel south") are subject to
inspection by Antarctic Treaty observers.

The Southern Ocean's southernmost port operates at McMurdo Station at [77°50′S
166°40′E﻿ / ﻿77.833°S 166.667°E﻿ / -77.833;
166.667](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Southern_Ocean&params=77_50_S_166_40_E_).
[Winter Quarters Bay](/wiki/Winter_Quarters_Bay "Winter Quarters Bay") forms a
small harbor, on the southern tip of [Ross Island](/wiki/Ross_Island "Ross
Island") where a floating [ice pier](/wiki/Ice_pier "Ice pier") makes port
operations possible in summer. [Operation Deep
Freeze](/wiki/Operation_Deep_Freeze "Operation Deep Freeze") personnel
constructed the first ice pier at McMurdo in 1973.[95]

Based on the original 1928 IHO delineation of the Southern Ocean (and the 1937
delineation if the [Great Australian Bight](/wiki/Great_Australian_Bight
"Great Australian Bight") is considered integral), Australian ports and
harbors between [Cape Leeuwin](/wiki/Cape_Leeuwin "Cape Leeuwin") and [Cape
Otway](/wiki/Cape_Otway "Cape Otway") on the Australian mainland and along the
west coast of [Tasmania](/wiki/Tasmania "Tasmania") would also be identified
as ports and harbors existing in the Southern Ocean. These would include the
larger ports and harbors of [Albany](/wiki/Albany,_Western_Australia "Albany,
Western Australia"), [Thevenard](/wiki/Thevenard,_South_Australia "Thevenard,
South Australia"), [Port Lincoln](/wiki/Port_Lincoln "Port Lincoln"),
[Whyalla](/wiki/Whyalla "Whyalla"), [Port
Augusta](/wiki/Port_Augusta,_South_Australia "Port Augusta, South Australia"),
[Port Adelaide](/wiki/Port_Adelaide "Port Adelaide"),
[Portland](/wiki/Portland,_Victoria "Portland, Victoria"),
[Warrnambool](/wiki/Warrnambool "Warrnambool"), and [Macquarie
Harbour](/wiki/Macquarie_Harbour "Macquarie Harbour").

[Yacht races](/wiki/Yacht_race "Yacht race") have been held in the Southern
Ocean, such as the [Volvo Ocean Race](/wiki/Volvo_Ocean_Race "Volvo Ocean
Race"), [Velux 5 Oceans Race](/wiki/Velux_5_Oceans_Race "Velux 5 Oceans
Race"), [Vendée Globe](/wiki/Vend%C3%A9e_Globe "Vendée Globe"), [Jules Verne
Trophy](/wiki/Jules_Verne_Trophy "Jules Verne Trophy") and [Global
Challenge](/wiki/Global_Challenge "Global Challenge").
